reviewText:
First and foremost do not let the simple presentation fool you, Sunrider Academy is a wonderful combination of VN, dating sim, and resource management; but it's the excellent writing that makes this game shine.  Both the artwork and music are neatly designed and fit the mood of the game well. Fan service is mild, with romance and WTF moments being the main theme (not graphic sex).

Each of the four girls you can date (and ultimately marry) have totally unique back stories that are a combination of: sweet, romantic, funny, and at times even dark and serious. Likewise each girl's personality is unique, making each relationship route wonderful in its own way. Even the good endings are totally different in overall personality. Dialogue is text only, but again it is VERY well written; even better than many big budget console games.

Advice: save Asaga for last because while each good ending is a happy one, hers is (in my opinion) the most romantic/cheerful ending.

Note: there are many funny inside jokes and easter eggs relating to Sunrider Mask of Arcadius.

Decision making is simple and occasionally funny, and will to some degree affect the girls' opinion of you. And it ~is~ possible to have more than one path oppen up to you--although you must ultimately choose one.

Design wonk: Stress" attribute accumulates way too fast. Player solution: turn difficulty to Casual or VN mode

Okay well to start off, i'm not giving this a bad review because I dislike the game. It is simply because it is way too stretched out and too long. Hah! Get it? Nvm... anyways.

I'll keep it simple and to the point. This game is a great visual novel, and the concept of it is great. This game expects you to make 4 playthroughs with all 4 girls and that's all fine and dandy. However, after about few hours into the game after talking a lot, events happening, and lots of things to do, you find yourself clickig the exact same things for long period of time without anything actually happening.

That's my whole problem. The game dies off after first few hours, and since you want to make at least one playthrough, you go long periods of drought without any events happening with the girls except your occasional club tournaments which become very repetative. But what is more repetative is you doing the same exact things every single day. Study, lunch, go for a walk, museum, arcade etc. At first it's a lot to do, but after a while it becomes so repetative that you want to rip your hair out.

This game could have been so much more amazing if it wouldn't be so stretched out with so much drought, or at least it was filled with so much things going on like the first few hours. If that couldn't be done, shortening it would do it much good. I also think that taking a route where you only have to do a playthrough with one girl is kinda boring. That's just my take.

Anyways, thanks for taking the time to read. If you want a great visual knowel this is it, and the pictures... well... you'll be satisfied. Be ready for the content drought though after first few hours though. Happy Adventures!

reviewText:
It really isn't that great unless you *really* enjoy resource management. You will be doing more of that than engaging in story elements. It gets repetitive very quickly, and can easily send your character on a death spiral if you don't stay on top of it.

Each of the girls themselves put the player on a second story arc for different late game endings. Although I appreciate the reality that girlfriends aren't simply handed to you on a silver platter, what I don't like is that you can enter one of these story arcs, miss a completely random encounter from week 3 or something that you would never have known about had you not looked up a guide for the game, and then have the story arc stall on you. This results in you reaching a mid to late game key calendar event without a girl willing to attend it with you, netting you a bad end.

Why let the player enter the story arc at all with the girl if something like that is going to ruin everything in the end? The player might even make it a few hours past entering the story arc before reaching the festival and then receiving bad end. Without at least one full playthrough, the player might not even be aware of their pending failure because of how heavily engrained the resource management gameplay is. Then, without looking up a guide, the player may fruitlessly try to recover and continue, simply hitting bad end over and over again because they didn't save early enough to hit any missing random encounters on the way through.

If it were not for the resource management gameplay, the game story line for all of the endings would likely last less than 10 hours. If the player plays the game on the lowest difficulty just so they might actually reach the ending, the gameplay itself will be boring and the fairly generic harem storylines won't make up for it.

Unless all you really want is a resouce management game, this game isn't worth $30, and probably isn't worth buying on sale unless you just want to collect a pile of visual novels for the sake of it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've bought this game and played through until February. Here are my thoughts.

-

First, I noticed that the graphics are improved from Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius. That's cool. You also have good use of chibi sprites, although I wish there was a little more variations during the competitions (Bronze, Silver and Gold having slightly different victory animations). I like the background, and they feel quite clean and modern.

-

The music is okay. There are just enough 'weekday' BGMs and 'weekend' BGMs so that they don't feel tiring to hear even after hours of gameplay, and the ones that do matter, the ones that are emotional are beautiful. Good to see one of the best asset of the Arcadius has not deteriorated coming into Academy.

I do wish that you'll add some voice acting in. I just love Sola's voice so much.

-

Now then, about the content. To be entirely honest, it feels really bare and empty at the moment. You have 100 days in a month, and most of those days are spent trying to beef up your stats and especially money so as to get a good result in competitions and exams.

The problem is that there is too much time, and too little content. For example, there aren't enough 'common' route scenes, scenes that automatically happen and does not require you to explore and discover. The first month is almost fine with the beginning scenes, the club captain meetings, the club competitions, Asaga screw up, final exams and festival. There may be 1 activable scene for each heroine if you visit the right places, which is okay.

But the second month is seriously bare. I'm assuming that there are again, 1 activable scenes for each heroine - I've found Asaga's at the arcade and Ava's at the student council room - some imouto scenes, and 1 common Ava scene at the end, but otherwise, almost nothing happened at all. Note that if this is the normal 30 days a month, this volume of content enough. However we are going through 50 days per month, and due to the nature of dating sims one can't help but save scum a little, which increases playtime more than it already is. To be entirely frank, at the end of Month 2 I was bored as hell.

Even worse, suppose that you're going for top rank for every competition, you actually do need all 50 days, spending as much time beefing the clubs, doing temp jobs at the Science Center, Strolling to reduce Stress and buy as many Readiness item as you can. And I've gotten the $50 Blanket from the beginning. After all the micromanagement I barely have a few days buffer which you again work frantically for the next club competition.

It was only near the end of Month 2 that I 'remembered' that this is a dating sim game, and that I should be looking about in different locations for extra scenes rather than buffing my stats even more, and I was incredibly reluctant to do so because ♥♥♥♥, I need to get that Retry Charm so the Swimming Club won't fail four days in a row because of I-have-no-idea-which-stats is screwing me up.

And as you add in more months into the game, the bar keeps rising higher, me as the player just will never have enough motivation to look out for additional scenes, which ironically is probably going to give me a  'YOU GOT NO GIRLFRIEND' bad end except probably Ava.

You try to keep us busy while keep the game balance by adding in negative stats when sleeping or doing certain activities - which I'm totally fine with, and is actually pretty realistic - but the ones that penalizes stats when visiting certain locations also greatly discourages exploration. For example I should be going to the Arcade often if I'm gunning for Asaga. but the fact that it gives -2 Int and -$2, with a possibility of failure leading to more penalty, just feels... well, maybe there's a better way.

On the other hand, visiting the Science Center is absolutely awesome. +3 Int, -1 Stress for just $2? Sign me up. It's just feels... like it can be balanced better. Again, one can almost forget this is a dating sim, because I care far more about getting better stats than trying to win the girls. Winning the girls become a side quest, one that can be ignored at least for the beginning months, and that's just really awkward in my opinion.

Of course, many of the above can be remedied with more fixed scenes of the girls. To begin with, I get to know them better. 100 days and 2 months into the game and I barely know, like, ANYTHING about them at all. With exception to the Ava scene at the end of Month 2, almost everything else is clown-ish scenes with no impact whatsoever. The Asaga ones are especially forgettable. Funny, but totally forgettable.

Fixed scenes also automatically raises the bar since that's one whole period lost, and then you can lower the penalties to encourage further explorations, which leads to people discovering activable scenes and start feeling that they're playing a dating sim.

The first 3 months should hook people into the game, not bounce them away with chores. It shouldn't be following a curve like X-Com's. I wouldn't mind if this bareness happen during say, Month 5 and beyond - at that point I should be know quite a bit about the girls in general, feeling good about it and at the same time somewhat frantic that I have little time to meet the next bar. That is when I'd like an empty month where I can really focus on the clubs and money, and not when I want to understand more about the girls.

-

About characters.

Asaga is quite funny at the beginning, with all the references and stuff. Hilarious even. But beyond the opening, she's like... non-existent. Maybe it's because this is just the beginning, and I heard there are more stories about her in Month 3. It just... she probably needs 1 more common scene (maybe all the girls do) in Month 2.

Chigara's standpoint is even worse than Asaga. She's just... I don't know. I'll wait.

Sola is... I know I shouldn't compare, but in Arcadius I feel like both her character and story is far more interesting and well-paced than here. Still, she has more character development than either of the above so it's cool.

You love Ava, don't you (or hate her the most - the point here is that it seems that you feel the strongest for her I think?)? One  papa scene and I feel completely captured by her. I think this is mostly the influence from Arcadius, but really.

-

About system.

You have all the basics in, and I believe you'll tweak the UI once you've completed the game. Text is too large (when in Arcadius it's too small, unless you're playing on a laptop), it's kind of cool and annoying at the same time you can totally flood the screen with every option possible - a bit more order here, surely. I don't think I need to comment on this, it's obvious this will be enhanced in the future.

The transition delay is a Ren'Py problem so it's cool.

-

I picked this up during the Anime weekend with a heavy discount. Even then I was a little unsure of spending even that much on something of this type. After playing it through all the way on each path, I must say it was well worth the discounted price, and probably the full price even. The story telling is engaging and interesting. In fact, many of the stories are downright fun. So many of these type of visual novels rely solely on explicit content to make it interesting. This story has that aspect (provided you install the patch), but my first play through did not have the patch and I felt the story was excellent even without. The stat management angle makes you have to put some thought into the story too, rather than just mindlessly clicking through.

As mentioned in the cons section, the stats management does become a bit repetitive at times. There are often long period between advancements in the storyline where you just go about your day to day activities. While in gameplay this can be a con, it can also be seen as mirroring real life, though some of the situations you're left questioning why an event that took place can have days go by without consequence or reaction. Keep in mind this game is LONG [9 months made of of 5 weeks, made up of 10 days] . With 4 paths to follow, either make a savepoint before you choose your path (roughly mid month 4 before you reach Pure Day, depending on stats), or be aware that you'll be redoing a lot of repetitive management to fulfill each storyline.
Another con mentioned was continuity. I did find that if you did not trigger certain encounters at the proper times, they could show up out of sequence. An example being if you do not meet with a club leader at the right time before the first competition, you may complete the competition, then the next day visit the club leader and have a discussion about preparing for that meet you’d just completed.

After building a connection with these characters, I was pleased to find that a lot of them are in two other games put out by this author. I plan on playing through those as well so I can get more out of these storylines.

Overall 10/10

Okay, so now that I have finished the game, I've decided to completely redo my review. First things first: Before you play this, at least play through most of the original game, Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius. It is free, it is wonderful, and this game contains a lot of references to that one. Seriously, it's phenomenal, free or not, and it's not even finished, another episode will be added later this year.

This games biggest weakness is pacing, both story-wise and gameplay-wise. The story pacing issues are made worse by the gameplay pacing issues, as sometimes reaching a certain even or fulfilling the requirements to trigger an event can either take a very long time, or if you didn't manage things well or hadn't yet figured out the game in the case of triggering an event, attempts to do so can make things more difficult for you.

The beginning of the game is very fast and doesn't explain itself well, and the end becomes a mindless cycle after the first go because nothing really matters at that point. For a game that requires multiple playthroughs to experience all the stories, the gameplay lacks variety, as the majority of the requirements are identical for each route. That said, once it's figured out, you can speed through the downtime fairly quickly, and if you find the stat managing gameplay unenjoyable or too difficult, there is a mode that makes it impossible to fail, so you can just experience the story, which is well worth the price alone, in my opinion.

As for the story, pacing is inconsistent. Each of the routes is paced differently, which is both good and bad. Good in that it keeps things varied, bad in that a couple of sections in a couple of the 4 routes available feel... slow. I found myself growing impatient, made worse by the fact that I was reaching the point in the game where the gameplay becomes a mindless routine where nothing is really significant. The slow sections have a purpose, and in the context of the story alone are understandable and meaningful, if not the most engaging, but they are made somewhat frustrating by the monotony of the gameplay during that portion of the route.

That pretty much covers the slightly more objective issues with the game. I personally don't really have many other criticisms, and no major ones to speak of. The music of the game is nice, but the tracks are rather short, and they loop during any given section, which can be annoying during particularly long story sequences. It didn't bother me much, but I did notice. Other little things include minor typos and slightly awkward phrasing, which were noticeable but didn't take away from the writing in any real sense.

So, on to the things that I like about the game. The writing is really strong. The stories that are told have great variety, strong plot twists, and generally have a lot of impact. The characters all have unique personalities and grow throughout the game, changing in various ways, doing unexpected things and genuinely surprising the player. This is true for all the routes, I found the stories told to be engaging, emotional, fun and heartwarming, and they all have their fair share of laughs. The support characters are all very interesting as well.

On to the art style. Its anime, okay? If you don't like anime, why are you here? That said, I don't feel that the art is generic or cliche. The character designs are all reasonably grounded, there are no crazy hair or overly stylized outfits, and each of the characters are easily distinguishable by more than just hair. The backgrounds are satisfactory. A couple of them are quite exceptional, the rest are just okay, but none of them are bad. The CG's are all nice as well, and while I do have my personal favorites, that is going to be a very personal preference, and all were of good quality.

TL:DR: This game has its issues. The first playthrough is tense and fun, well paced with common events, the following 3 to finish the remaining routes suffer from a lack of challenge and slower pacing due to already having experienced the common events. Outside of that, I absolutely adored this game, and didn't feel that these issues lessened my enjoyment too greatly. The characters are great, the writing does nearly everything right, there is a lot of variety story-wise, and the art is all high-quality and thoroughly enjoyable. I wholeheartedly recommend this one, but if you have yet to play the original game, Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius, play it first. It is great, it's free, and it makes this game a better experience.

FAIR WARNING: the game as it is is currently neutered thanks to a silly policy of Steam's.  Be sure to download the patch that restores all content.  It's free and endorsed by the developers, because they know this policy is just a formality Steam has to inflict.

You can get it at sunrider(dash)vn(dot)com.

Also, I've played this game for about twelve hours, total, but steam doesn't believe it because I played it offline.

Now, on to the proper review:  at the current point in time, I cannot recommend this game for the price offered.

It is a working, functional game, but it feels unpolished and honestly inferior to Sunrider Mask of Arcadius, which left something to be desired with the game design but ultimately felt like a better reading experience in general.  The presence of more characters helps to show more of those characters off by providing more interactions between them all.

The tone of the game feels more 'silly' than 'light-hearted', to the extent that even I found myself a little disappointed.  And the silliness doesn't work for it like the light-hearted but occasionally grim tone of Mask of Arcadius.  I understand why the game was limited to four routes (if you had to balance more than three clubs you'd be boned, probably), but I feel like inclusion of adaptations of other characters from the original game could have helped to flesh out the character interactions and make the game feel less empty.

With regards to the management sim part of the game, it often feels like most of my failures were due to 'tantrum spirals' rather than actual tactical errors.  'Failed' events bump stress, and you fail events with more stress.  Failed 'jobs' give you less money, which you primarily spend to win and to reduce stress.  Too much stress makes you unable to win the game...

Of course, if you have any problems with the game on regular difficulty, you can easily win the game on the second difficulty level.  True to form, Love in Space has made the normal difficulty too hard for the average player...but this game is no where near as hard as Mask of Arcadius was (thanks be to whatever patron spirits are in charge of visual novels).

I warn against playing on Waifu mode because it makes it too hard to control which girl you actually want to get with (you can't just duff 'random encounters' to keep a girl's affection from rising), but it does aptly fulfill its role.  I don't like the nature of the 'random encounters' either, but that comes with this territory.

Sola's route was the only one I've done so far, and it's okay, but there's an issue with a major plot point and how the Swim Club works between two certain points in the story.  I know it's a bit of handwavium, but I also feel like it should have been addressed somehow.

With regards to purchasing it, I would honestly wait until they put out a few patches to tighten it up a bit.  It's not a bad or broken game, but it's not a good one either.  I just don't like it, and I can't recommend it for the price it's offered at (even at the present sale) until they clean it up a bit.  I don't know if they PLAN to clean it up a bit, so buyer beware.

Update:

I've played the other three routes by now.

I still like reading the scenes, but it still feels especially poor as a management sim, if only because of how grindy it is.

Chigara's route is a little iffy, but Chigara's not my favorite girl anyway.  I did like that it ended with babies and a bakery, because who doesn't love pregnancy?  (Well, okay, I like pregnancy)

Ava's route is totally Ava, tied for second best with Asaga.

Asaga is awesome, as per usual.

I don't understand what the heck 'mou' is or why Ceran women say things that make me think of cow sounds.

Disclaimer: Steam botched up my hours played and says (as of this writing) I only have two hours. I timed myself. I played for 5. Not saying it makes a huge difference, but I'm stating it to credit my experience with the game so far.

I was a bit put off by this game at first. I was afraid it would end up being another one of those graphic novels in the guise of an actual game, however after reading a few existing reviews I bought it myself and was pleasantly surprised. This is a management game with actual gameplay, even if it is all revolved around being in the right menu at the right time and clicking words.

I also wasn't very impressed with the character designs. Having a girlfriend that draws constantly, I've learned to pick details out of designs, and there wasn't anything overall impressive with these. However, this is due to a combination of setting, and the fact that the characters you meet in the game are more than just their appearance.

Sunrider Academy takes place, as is obvious, in an academy! Your job as the player is to take the role of a club manager, and to help several misfit, down-on-their-luck clubs get their members count, morale, and skills up in order to prevent them from being  discontinued. You also have to simultaneously keep your own skills up and complete your school work, as you are still a student. There's also this, arguably unnecessary, sub objective in which you need to get a girlfriend out of all of this, and since each club you help is being led by an adorable anime waifu, your not exactly short of girls to woo.

If you already are into these kind of games, you'll more than likely find yourself completely invested in both the characters and the gameplay in a matter of 30 minutes. reviewText:
Great art direction, amazing music, nice premise... but this is an extremely mediocre VN.

90% of the game is repetitive clicking. It's more of a stat management game than a visual novel. At first there is a lot to do, but then you realize there is nothing else to do but wait for several in-game months for any events to happen. After my first playthrough I had to use the dev console to play all the other routes without the boring RNG management.

The writing is utterly bland. The game relies too much on tropes and cliches that the endings were predictable. But to my surprise all the endings weren't what I expected, instead they made no sense whatsoever. Like for example, a lifelong sibling rivalry that magically disappears overnight and the protagonist refusing to dump his psychological abuser of a girlfriend, and a lifelong-planned business marriage that was cancelled and the groom totally fine giving the protagonist the girl. The endings felt rushed, unresolved, and unrealistic.

I mean you will probably enjoy this game to an extent, but other than looking at numbers, you'll spend most of your time yelling at the screen telling the main character that he is ret*rded. But you can't do anything because dialogue options are non-existent -- it's just a pre-written story with pictures and numbers.

The game is simple: Keep the clubs and their presidents in line, keep your notes in order and arrange a girlfriend.

reviewText:
A mediocre to poor offering from the creators of the first free-to-play Sunrider.  As far as visual novels go, it isn't particularily engaging and down right boring at times.  While there is some amusing dialog, much of it is forced, and the author isn't very good at creating characters one can actually like.  The main character is prone to cartoon violence and condescension . . . he pats women on the head, hits thems regularly as if they were one of the Three Stooges, and verbally assaults them with language that may have been thought funny at the time but instead comes across as mean and hateful.

Gameplay-wise, the daily management sim is uninspired and soon becomes a chore.

The art is pretty good with a few oddities.   Those expecting a full-blown eroge will be disappointed.

If this is dirt cheap and you're a fan of the free Sunrider game, go ahead, otherwise, don't waste your money.

This game has been out a while and already has a large amount of positive reviews but I wanted to give my opinion on it because of the profound experience I had while playing it. The most obvious thing about Sunrider Academy was that it became one of the most addicting games I have ever played. This was both good and bad because at times it was extremely fun and at other times very tedious and repetitive. I've had games where I loved the game but became frustrated with certain parts, but Sunrider Academy was unique in that despite its problems my attention and admiration towards it never changed. The game created a hugely enjoyable experience which was worthy of the time I invested in it (I spent a great deal of time playing it). It provides a unique blend of visual novel/dating sim with a time management system and requires you to spend your time carefully or risk a “bad ending”. There are 4 routes with 4 different girls which allows for a good amount of replay. As a fan of visual novel games I usually find that most of them are short and give very few things to do besides clicking through dialogue. At its core it is a simple Visual Novel but it adds so much more to the experience and provides beautiful visuals, interesting characters and emotional story telling. I don't like to rate games by each concept of the game but solely by the emotional experience I had with it. If I found my time enjoyable and an positive impression was left after playing then I feel it was a good game. Sunrider Academy did this better then any game has in a while and I would highly recommend.

Think of a simple numbers management game (like Game Dev) with a story and you have Sunrider Academy.

You have to help manage a college (and a few college teams) to success while avoiding a 'bad end' from illness, stress, team failure, exam failure, romantic failure ...... etc.

The number mechanics are very simple, not that variable and - once you learn the pattern - a simple routine will pretty much ensure you success on the path you chose. And you do have to repeat that pattern. And repeat, and repeat, and repeat, and repeat, and repeat, and repeat, and repeat, and repeat it ......... to build the numbers and gradually hear the story. Frankly, It doesn't sound like much fun BUT, once you start hearing the characters 'backstories' you will want to help them 'win'. Well, if you like 'story' games and you have any empathy and humanity in you, you do. And thats the good anime games in summary - good character/story, but grinding mechanics.

As an aside, the college teams budget preparation element of this game is so realistic its spooky.

I bought this together with the Sunriders:Mask space battle game. The characters in this game all appear in Mask as ships crew. Which is a somewhat odd feeling when you play Mask after Academy (and Mask takes no account of your Academy path) .

This is a game you will probably play in short bursts over a long timescale. If you see it on sale, its an interesting enough anime story game.

I don't know much about the Sunrider series but I'm pretty sold off this spinoff. Granted the game has issues, but it's totally worth trying out. After playing the first path I think I'm inclined to play again despite the grinding.

Grinding is really ridiculous in this game. So much so it felt for weeks on end (especially after you choose your arc) needless. Granted the arc (Sora) was worth the time, I really wish there was a faster way to getting through the grinding and back to the story. The fact that once you choose an arc you pretty much don't see the remainder of the cast is pretty disappointing.
